title: Ending Life, Morality, and Meaning
abstract: Opponents of voluntary euthanasia and physician-assisted suicide often maintain that the procedures ought not to be accepted because ending an innocent human life would both be morally wrong in itself and have unfortunate consequences. A gravely suffering patient can grant that ending his life would involve such harm but still insist that he would have reason to continue living only if there were something to him in his abstaining from ending his life. Though relatively rarely, the notion of meaning of life has figured in recent medical ethical debate on voluntary euthanasia and physician-assisted suicide. And in current philosophical discussion on meaning of life outside the medical ethical debate on voluntary euthanasia and physician-assisted suicide several authors have argued that being moral and having a meaningful existence are connected to each other. In this article, I assess whether his intentionally refraining from causing the harm related to voluntary euthanasia and physician-assisted suicide would involve something to such a patient in the sense that it would promote the meaningfulness of his life.

motivations: There is ongoing debate and controversy surrounding the morality and consequences of voluntary euthanasia and physician-assisted suicide.
Patients suffering greatly may see no value in continuing their life unless there is personal significance or meaning in abstaining from ending it.
objectives: Assess whether a patient's decision to refrain from voluntary euthanasia or physician-assisted suicide could contribute to the meaningfulness of their life.
Explore the connection between morality, the meaning of life, and the decision to end one's life in the context of medical ethics.
methods: Analyze the philosophical discussion on the meaning of life and its relation to morality.
Evaluate the arguments for and against voluntary euthanasia and physician-assisted suicide in medical ethics.
results: Provide insight into whether a patient's choice to abstain from ending their life could add meaning to their existence.
Contribute to the ongoing debate on the morality and ethics of voluntary euthanasia and physician-assisted suicide.
llama_json.research_subject: The relationship between morality, the meaning of life, and voluntary euthanasia or physician-assisted suicide

motivations: There is a debate on whether voluntary euthanasia and physician-assisted suicide are morally wrong and have unfortunate consequences.
The concept of life's meaning has been relatively rarely discussed in the context of voluntary euthanasia and physician-assisted suicide.
There is a need to explore the connection between morality, meaning of life, and decisions related to voluntary euthanasia and physician-assisted suicide.
objectives: Examine the moral implications of voluntary euthanasia and physician-assisted suicide.
Investigate the role of life's meaning in the debate on voluntary euthanasia and physician-assisted suicide.
Assess whether refraining from voluntary euthanasia and physician-assisted suicide can promote the meaningfulness of a patient's life.
methods: Analyze the ethical debate on voluntary euthanasia and physician-assisted suicide.
Explore the philosophical discussion on the meaning of life outside the medical ethical debate.
Evaluate the potential connection between morality, meaningful existence, and decisions related to voluntary euthanasia and physician-assisted suicide.
results: Provide insights into the moral dimensions of voluntary euthanasia and physician-assisted suicide.
Contribute to the understanding of life's meaning in the context of end-of-life decisions.
Clarify the potential impact of refraining from voluntary euthanasia and physician-assisted suicide on the meaningfulness of a patient's life.
openai_json.research_subject: The moral and existential implications of voluntary euthanasia and physician-assisted suicide

motivations: The debate on voluntary euthanasia and physician-assisted suicide raises questions about whether ending life is morally wrong and what consequences it may have.
Patients experiencing grave suffering may question whether continuing to live has meaning when faced with unbearable circumstances.
objectives: Assess whether intentionally refraining from voluntary euthanasia or physician-assisted suicide could promote meaningfulness in a suffering patient's life.
Examine the connection between morality and meaningful existence in the context of end-of-life decisions.
methods: Philosophical analysis of the relationship between morality, meaning of life, and end-of-life decisions.
Examination of arguments from medical ethics and philosophical discussions on meaning of life.
anthropic_json.research_subject: The relationship between morality, meaning of life, and end-of-life decisions in voluntary euthanasia and physician-assisted suicide
